options: Suggest she call 111 and offer to go with her to the out-of-hours/hospital if they deem this appropriate
Suggest she makes an appointment with her GP to review her analgesia in the morning
Send her a link to the GMC website explaining the rules out not prescribing to friends/family
Review her current medication and give advice on optimising over-the-counter analgesia
Prescribe a small dose of morphine sulphate liquid to manage her pain until she can be reviewed properly the next day
questions:
You are a junior doctor who has just commenced work in gastroenterology. You arrive home from work one evening to a voicemail message from your aunt. She sounds upset and begs that you help her. She says that nothing is helping her pain and that only morphine will work. She then asks if you would write her out a prescription.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
This is a difficult situation as someone you care about is obviously struggling.

The best course of action, one that both addresses your aunt's problem whilst keeping within professional guidelines is A. This ensures she is reviewed quickly by an independent doctor. This is better than waiting until the morning (B). Whilst it seems that she has long term pain problems it is possible there is an acute issue that is not being addressed.

Sending her a link to GMC guidance (C) does not deal with her pain but at least ensures you maintain an appropriate professional distance,

Whilst D may sound harmless you would not be able to give safe advice without knowing her full medical history as common medications such as NSAIDs can have serious side-effects and contraindications.

The worst response is E. You are both breaking professional guidelines by prescribing to a family member but also practising unsafely by prescribing without assessing the patient.

title: GMC: treating friends, family and colleagues
body: The GMC guidance of 'Good practice in prescribing and managing medicines and device's says that wherever possible you must avoid prescribing for yourself or anyone with whom you have a close personal relationship, and they state that 'We expect our registrants to follow our guidance'.
concept: Treating friends and family is not acceptable

options: Refer to ENT
Tell the patient you think she has too much ear wax and arrange ear syringing
Ask the patient to come back for review in 2 weeks, in the meantime look up possible causes of this finding
Tell the patient the examination was normal and not to worry about it
Ask your GP trainer to have a look
questions:
During morning surgery a 43-year-old woman presents with dizziness. She is a frequent attendee and has been diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome previously. As part of a routine examination you notice findings on otoscopy that you have not seen before. The tympanic membrane looks abnormal but you are not sure if it is just wax. You have never seen anything similar before and are unsure about the diagnosis.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question is mainly about the ability to recognise your own limits.

It is clear from the scenario that you are unsure what the otoscopy findings represent and hence it is appropriate to ask for advice. Your trainer may have seen similar findings previously and hence is the first person to ask. The next best option if you are unsure is to refer to ENT for a more definitive opinion.

Asking the patient to come back after you've had chance to look things up at least represents an element of safety netting.

Instigating treatment such as syringing may be potentially harmful if the diagnosis is incorrect (e.g. if there is an underlying perforation).

Telling the patient that the examination was normal is effectively lying and hence unacceptable.

options: Remove all acronyms and abbreviations then send the same request again.
Phone radiology and politely explain the situation and ask how you can improve the request

questions:
You request an urgent chest X-ray at the request of your consultant, but he has now left the hospital for a clinic elsewhere. The radiology department refuses your request but doesn't explain why.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Interdepartmental communication is essential, and phoning to ask why will ultimately help you in the future as well as with this patient (B). Whilst phoning the department is quicker it is also reasonable to visit the department in person to discuss with the duty radiologist (E)

Asking someone more senior may be useful (C), but only if you watch how they do it and learn from it. Removing the acronyms may help (A) but this may not be the reason the request form was refused and most acronyms are well understood by medical personnel.

Exaggerating symptoms is dishonest (D) and may lead to someone more ill having to wait unnecessarily.

questions:
You are a junior doctor working in the Emergency Department. You are sat at the nurses' station filling in paperwork when a man interrupts you. He says that his friend was admitted last night and asks if you know about his condition and if it would be possible to see him. You do not recognise the man but were involved in the patient's treatment before he was moved to another ward. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
You must be clear with anyone asking for information about a patient that this cannot be disclosed without consent. Once you have informed them of this it may be possible to find out if the patient would like to see them or if they are happy for you to give this person information about them. The obvious choice would then be to attempt to locate the patient.

Telling the friend to ask someone else removes you from the situation but is unhelpful and could come across as rude and obstructive.

Telling the friend that you do not know the patient is not only unhelpful but also a lie. Dishonesty is unacceptable as per the GMC guidance.

If you tell the friend that the patient has had a heart attack you have clearly broken confidentiality without their permission.

title: GMC guidance: Confidentiality
body:
The UK General Medical Council (GMC) provides guidelines on confidentiality to help doctors maintain trust with their patients and respect their right to privacy. Here is a summary of the key principles in GMC's guidance on confidentiality:
  • Patients' right to privacy: Doctors must respect patients' right to privacy and should not disclose their personal information without consent, unless required by law or justified by the public interest.
  • Obtaining consent: Whenever possible, doctors should obtain explicit consent from patients before disclosing their information. The consent should be informed and given freely, and patients should understand the potential consequences of sharing their information.
  • Anonymization: When using patient information for purposes such as teaching, research, or quality improvement, doctors should anonymize the data whenever possible to protect patients' identities.
  • Disclosures in the public interest: In exceptional circumstances, doctors may disclose patient information without consent if it is in the public interest, such as to prevent serious harm to others or in response to communicable diseases that pose a risk to public health.
  • Legal requirements: Doctors must comply with legal requirements to disclose patient information, such as court orders or statutory reporting obligations.
  • Confidentiality after death: Doctors should continue to respect patients' confidentiality even after their death, unless there are compelling reasons to disclose information.
  • Sharing information with the healthcare team: Doctors may share patient information within the healthcare team on a need-to-know basis to provide safe and effective care.
  • Record-keeping: Doctors should maintain accurate, up-to-date, and secure records to protect patient information and ensure its confidentiality.
  • Communicating with patients: Doctors should communicate openly and honestly with patients about their right to confidentiality and how their information may be used.
  • Working with third parties: When working with third parties, such as insurers or employers, doctors should ensure that they have appropriate consent from patients before sharing their information.

options: Raise your concerns with the mother and ask her to make an appointment with you
Advise the mother on how to smack without causing bruising / leaving any mark
Raise your concerns with the mother and contact the local Child Protection Officer
Contact the local Child Protection Officer without informing her first
Take no action
questions:
After work you are shopping in the local supermarket when you see one of your female patients smacking her 2-year-old son on the back of the legs and torso. You had seen the same child last month and had noticed a bruise on his upper arms which had been put down to falling over.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
As the law currently stands it is only legal to smack your child if it does not leave a mark. Given that you have previously seen the child with a bruise and have now seen the mother smack the child it is reasonable to report your concerns to the local Child Protection Officer. It is good practice to inform the mother what you are going to do.

Asking the mother to make an appointment with you will allow you to discuss your concerns in a more private setting but delays the necessary action being taken.

By taking no action you are ignoring an opportunity to potential protect a child who is at risk. Giving tips on how to smack a child without bruising is clearly the wrong option.

options: Continue to work ensuring that you do not to have any direct contact with patients
Continue to work and ensure that all of the jobs are completed to the best of your abilities
Immediately inform your supervisor and team that you are unable to attend work. Stay off work for 48 hours following resolution of symptoms

Take the day off and hope that the symptoms resolve with a plan to go back to work tomorrow
questions:
You are the Foundation Year 2 doctor working in a busy general medical ward. There is a Norovirus outbreak on your ward. During the week you develop diarrhoea and vomiting. You are worried that the team will not cope without you.

Rank in order the appropriateness of the following actions in response to this situation (1= Most appropriate; 5= Least appropriate).
notes:
This question highlights the importance of protecting patients from infectious diseases as well as protecting yourself when unwell.

Option C is the best option as you are correctly staying off work to prevent the spread of infection. Informing your team and supervisor is essential so that possible cover can be arranged. Ensuring that you stay off until 48 hours after the resolution of symptoms is also essential for reducing the spread of infection.

Option D is less appropriate as infection control has not been informed, and there is no mention of returning to work after 48 hours of resolution of symptoms.

Option E is preferable over the remaining options as it will reduce the risk of spreading the infection. However, it is not as ideal as options C or D as it does not involve informing your supervisor or team.

Option A is entirely inappropriate. Although you have no direct contact with patients you will risk spreading the infection to colleagues. However, it is a better option than Option B which puts patients at significant risk of harm.

title: GMC guidance: doctor's health
body:
The General Medical Council (GMC) makes it explicitly clear that you should not rely on your own judgement of the risk posed by your health to your patients. They state that this should be done by an 'appropriately qualified healthcare professional'. You must seek and follow their advice on any changes to your work necessary. In this case therefore, the only appropriate choice is to consult occupational health.

Risks posed to patients by your own health
  • 'If you know or suspect that you have a serious condition that you could pass on to patients, or if your judgement or performance could be affected by a condition or its treatment, you must consult a suitably qualified colleague.'
  • 'You must follow their advice about any changes to your practice they consider necessary.'
  • 'You must not rely on your own assessment of the risk to patients.'

Good Medical Practice, domain 2, subsections 28-30, GMC 2013

options: Call the registrar back explaining your concerns again and why you would like a medical review
Phone the medical consultant on-call and explain your concerns
Tell the patient to go to A&E herself with a written letter explaining the situation
Respect the opinion of the registrar and monitor the patient at home
Tell the patient to go to A&E herself but avoid writing a letter so as not to offend the admitting medical team
questions:
You are an F2 doctor in General Practice and review a 23-year-old who presented with headache, muscle aches and fever. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.3ºC and complains of some neck and back pains. You feel the most likely diagnosis is influenza but are concerned about the possibility of meningitis given the neck pain. On phoning the hospital you speak to the medical registrar who feels that the presentation sounds very much like the flu and doesn't think admission is necessary. On asking the registrar to accept the patient he refuses, tells you he's got to go as he is 'so busy with referrals' and puts the phone down.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Whilst the tempting thing is to have a row with the medical registrar this scenario looks for a more professional approach. Whilst it is true that the most likely cause for the patient's symptoms is influenza it is not unreasonable to want to exclude meningitis.

The best course of action is to try again with the registrar (A). You may have caught the registrar at 'a bad time' and it is worthwhile explaining your concerns again.

If this fails the consultant on-call should be spoken to (B). They after all are in charge of the admitting medical team. As you have concerns about the patient it is important that they are seen in secondary care. It is therefore reasonable to send the patient to A&E for assessment (C), and more professional to give the patient a letter explaining the situation (E).

It is clear from the scenario that the medical registrar has not made an appropriate assessment of the patient. As you have concerns it is therefore a poor option to monitor the patient at home (D).

options: Ring the patient's wife and tell her immediately
Discuss the reasoning behind the patient not wanting to tell his wife
Warn the patient that if he does not tell his wife about his diagnosis then you will have to breach confidentiality to tell her
Don't inform the patient's wife as it would breach his confidentiality

questions:
You are a registrar working in general practice. You see a 30-year-old male in your morning surgery and have to inform him that he has HIV. On further questioning, he reveals that he does not plan on telling his wife, but intends on continuing to have intercourse with her.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The main themes in this question are those of confidentiality, when to break it and public safety.

Discussing the reasoning behind the patient not wanting to tell his wife (option 2) is the best option in this case. This will help to uncover the underlying worries and concerns and you as a clinician may be able to help. Just talking about the patient's concerns with you may have a therapeutic effect on him. If this did not work then you still have the option of option 3, however it would be best practice to try this approach first.

Warning the patient that if he does not tell his wife about his diagnosis then you will have to breach confidentiality to tell her (option 3) is the next best option in this case. The GMC guidance on breaking confidentiality with regards to communicable diseases states the following:


'Disclosure of personal information about a patient without consent may be justified in the public interest if failure to disclose may expose others to a risk of death or serious harm. You should still seek the patient's consent to disclosure if practicable and consider any reasons given for refusal.'

In this scenario, the patient is placing his placing his wife at risk of death or serious harm. Therefore, breaching confidentiality can be justified. Option 3 is more preferable to option 1, however, as you are giving the patient the opportunity to inform his wife himself, as opposed to you doing it for him immediately.

Options 5 and 4 are the worst options in this scenario. This is because both options place the patient's wife at risk of contracting HIV. Option 4 is ranked slightly higher, however, as you are trying to minimise the risk of her contracting the disease by using barrier methods, whereas option 4 involves doing nothing.

options: Ask for the patient's consent to take a blood sample
Stop the procedure
Complete a Datix
Ask a colleague to insert the cannula for you
Inform the ward sister of the incident
questions:
You are a junior doctor working on the liver unit. You are attempting to insert a cannula and unfortunately obtain a needlestick injury. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
The first priority is to ensure you have administered effective first aid on your injury. You should immediately stop what you are doing, go to a sink and hold under running water, encouraging it to bleed. Then, wash with plenty of soap and water, dry and cover with a dressing. The next step you should take is to inform someone, ideally the sister of the ward where the incident occurred. He/she can then assign an appropriate person to perform the risk assessment and consent the patient for blood taking. The key message here is that you should not do this yourself. This is to prevent coercion. You will need to inform occupational health as soon as possible so that they can advise on next steps.

The patient will still need a cannula inserting and so the next most important thing to do would be to ask a colleague to put one for you while you sort yourself out. Completing a Datix needs to be done but not necessarily in the immediate aftermath of the incident. The worst response would be to ask for consent to take a blood sample from the patient yourself, as this is not appropriate it as explained above.

title: Post-exposure prophylaxis
body:
Hepatitis A
  • Human Normal Immunoglobulin (HNIG) or hepatitis A vaccine may be used depending on the clinical situation
    • HNIG is typically reserved for those who cannot receive the vaccine or where rapid protection is required (e.g. immunosuppressed individuals)
    • In most cases, hepatitis A vaccine is preferred for post-exposure prophylaxis

Hepatitis B
  • HBsAg positive source
    • If the person exposed is a known responder (anti-HBs ≥10 mIU/mL following full vaccination), a booster dose should be given
    • If they are a non-responder (anti-HBs <10 mIU/mL 1–2 months after completing the full course), they should receive hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) and a booster vaccine
  • Unknown source
    • For known responders, a booster dose may be considered depending on the risk assessment
    • For non-responders, HBIG and a booster vaccine should be given
    • Individuals undergoing a primary course of vaccination should complete an accelerated schedule and may be offered HBIG if the risk of exposure is considered high

Hepatitis C
  • There is no effective post-exposure prophylaxis for hepatitis C
  • Initial testing should include baseline HCV serology and HCV RNA (PCR)
  • Repeat HCV RNA at 6 and 12 weeks post-exposure, and HCV antibody at 3 and 6 months
  • If seroconversion occurs, early referral to hepatology for consideration of direct-acting antiviral therapy is advised

HIV
  • The risk of HIV transmission depends on the nature of the exposure (e.g. needlestick, type of sexual contact, human bite) and the viral load of the source individual
  • Low-risk incidents such as human bites generally do not require post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), unless blood is present or other risk factors apply
  • First-line PEP regimen is oral antiretroviral therapy: tenofovir disoproxil/emtricitabine (Truvada®) + raltegravir
    • PEP should be started as soon as possible (ideally within 1–2 hours, and no later than 72 hours post-exposure)
    • Treatment course lasts 4 weeks
  • HIV serological testing is required at 12 weeks after completing PEP
  • PEP reduces the risk of HIV transmission by approximately 80%

Varicella zoster
  • Varicella zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG) should be given to IgG-negative pregnant women or immunosuppressed individuals after significant exposure
    • If VZIG is unavailable or >10 days post-exposure, oral aciclovir may be considered (based on risk assessment)

options: Document clearly in the notes
Use the MHA to give the medication
Accept his decision to refuse treatment
Use the Mental Capacity Act to give the medication
Assess his mental state
questions:
You are the junior doctor on-call in an inpatient psychiatric unit. You have been asked to speak with a gentleman who is currently on a section 3 of the Mental Health Act due to a relapse of paranoid schizophrenia. He has a known diagnosis of bowel cancer but this morning refused his morning dose of Xeloda, a tablet chemotherapy agent. He says he is fed up of taking it as it gives him diarrhoea. You are satisfied that he fully understands the risks of not taking it. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
The fact that a person has a mental illness does not automatically mean they lack capacity to make a decision about medical treatment. If once you have assessed the patient's capacity (i.e. his ability to understand, believe, retain and weigh the necessary information including risks and benefits) and established that he has the capacity to refuse this treatment, you must accept his decision, even if it seems irrational or may put his health/life at risk. The MHA provides a statutory framework, which sets out when patients can be compulsorily treated for a mental disorder without consent, to protect them or others from harm. Patients cannot be compulsorily treated for a physical condition under the terms of the MHA. If the patient lacks capacity to make a decision regarding treatment of physical health conditions, at this point you would use the Mental Capacity Act.

In this situation once you have assessed his mental capacity and deemed him to have capacity to make this decision, you would have to respect that. You should make a clear entry in the notes of this assessment and decision. Assessing his mental state is not required to inform your decision on treatment of physical health conditions such as this, provided that he has capacity, but may help in making a holistic assessment of his general needs. Answer D is wrong as you have deemed that he has capacity and therefore the right to refuse treatment. However, the worst response would be to treat him compulsorily under the MHA, because whether he has capacity or not, you cannot use it to treat a physical health condition.

LINKED GUIDANCE: Legal annex, consent, GMC ethical guidance; Re C (Adult: refusal of treatment) [1994] 1 All ER 819 (QBD)

title: Consent
body:
There are 3 types of consent:

1. Informed
2. Expressed
3. Implied

Consent forms used in UK NHS
Consent Form 1For competent adults who are able to consent for themselves where consciousness may be impaired (e.g. GA)
Consent Form 2For an adult consenting on behalf of a child where consciousness is impaired
Consent Form 3For an adult or child where consciousness is not impaired
Consent Form 4For adults who lack capacity to provide informed consent

Capacity
Key points include:
1. Understand and retain information
2. Patient believes the information to be true
3. Patient is able to weigh the information to make a decision
All patients must be assumed to have capacity

Consent in minors
Young children and older children who are not Gillick competent cannot consent for themselves. In British law the patient's biological mother can always provide consent. The childs father can consent if the parents are married (and the father is the biological father), or if the father is named on the birth certificate (irrespective of marital status). If parents are not married and the father is not named on the birth certificate then the father cannot consent.
